Kerosene contains alkanes from about n=10 to n=16. Above n=17 they are solids at room temperature. Petroleum or crude oil is a mixture of hydrocarbons, mainly alkanes, formed by the decay of the remains of sea creatures and plants over millions of years. Fractional distillation. The complex mixture of hydrocarbons is separated into smaller mixtures or fractions by fractional distillation (primary distillation). The crude oil is heated and the vapour/ liquid mixture passed into a tower. Combustion of alkanes. In common with all hydrocarbons, alkanes bum in air or oxygen in very exothermic reactions. In the presence of a plentiful supply of oxygen, complete combustion of alkanes occurs to form carbon dioxide and water.

Diesel fuel is a mixture of hydrocarbons—with boiling points in the range of 150 to 380°C—which are obtained from petroleum. Petroleum crude oils are composed of hydrocarbons of three major classes: (1) paraffinic, (2) naphthenic (or cycloparaffinic), and (3) aromatic hydrocarbons. Most of the compounds in diesel fuel are hydrocarbons of the paraffinic, naphthenic, or aromatic class. Diesel fuel also contains small quantities of organic compounds of sulfur (e.g., dibenzothiophene), nitrogen (e.g., carbazole), and oxygen.

Abstract: Diesel fuel is a mixture of hydrocarbons obtained by distillation of crude oil. The important properties which are used to characterize diesel fuel include cetane number (or cetane index), fuel volatility, density, viscosity, cold behavior, and sulfur content. Most of the compounds in diesel fuel are hydrocarbons of the paraffinic, naphthenic, or aromatic class. Diesel fuel also contains small quantities of organic compounds of sulfur (e.g., dibenzothiophene), nitrogen (e.g., carbazole), and oxygen.
